content.value: This document provides a complete guide for integrating the Widgets Management System (v1.1) into your Unreal Engine projects. It is designed for modularity, using interface-driven communication and decomposed widgets to ensure effortless integration and extension.
Support: For questions or assistance, please leave a comment on the product page or join the Discord server for faster resolution. Please consider rating and reviewing the asset if it proves useful.

value: • GameMode Logic: The BP_WMSGameMode GameMode handles the management of on-screen widgets (creation, removal, and updates).

• Modular Design:
    • The system is heavily interface-driven.
• Widgets are decomposed into reusable elements to unify style and logic across different screens.
• AddWidgetToScreen: This interface function is used for drawing widgets with game mode as target.
• Copy/Migrate the entire WidgetsManagementSystem folder to your project.
Set your game mode to BP_WMSGameMode
• Play!
To use your custom game mode :
• Add BPI_GameModeInterface to your game mode.
• Copy the implementation logic from BP_WMSGameMode to your custom game mode.
• Create required variables and fill necessary data.
• Done!
Make sure BPC_PlayerAttributes Component is added to your character blueprint.
It is required for maintaining the camera movement when widget screen is changed.
• If you switched to using your custom GameMode, you may need to fix up some references in the demo widgets.
• Since widgets management is the focus of this system, the player character does not has animation data. It is always stuck in T-Pose.
• The character and camera movement may be janky.
• The PauseMenu implementation uses DebugKeyTAB for creating pause menu on screen. It may not work in final game if the debug key is not replaced with actual input key.
<li>Also when pause menu is drawn, only the inputs are disabled. Any other activity happening in the background won't stop.
• For example -NPC Activity in the background that does not uses inputs from player character.
• Widget Architecture: Screens are simplified by reusable Widget Elements (prefixed with E_).
• Level Sequences: Level Sequences can now be played in the background of any widget.

• Quality of Life:
    • Fixed camera rotation during gameplay
    • Fixed cursor visibility issues.
• Add or modify existing categories in the enumeration E_WidgetScreen.
• Open DA_PDA_WidgetData in DataAsset folder.
• Either empty the array to use your own widgets for each category or click the plus (+) icon to add a new element in the array.
• Assign your newly created or desired category to the WidgetState variable.
• Select your required widget blueprint in the WidgetElement category.
• Select if or not you want level sequences to be played in the background when this category widget is drawn on screen by toggling PlayLevelSequence variable.
• LevelSequences contains the array of level sequences data which can be played in the background of the respective widget.
• PlayableSequence is the level sequence that can be played in the background.
• PlayRate can be used to speed up or down the level sequences.
• Transform data is used to adjusting the position of Level sequence with respect to the player.
• It is recommended not to add multiple data elements for same category. In every case, only the earliest found category data will be used.
• Do not toggle PlayLevelSequence ON if the LevelSequences array is empty.
• If the LevelSequences array is not empty, then make sure the array elements contain valid data. I haven't implemented check for valid data entry. So you may get some errors if you will do so.

• The level sequences will always be played relative to player location. So wherever you have placed the PlayerStart in the world, the player character will spawn there and the level sequences will be played in that area.
• Your level sequences are not affected by anything in the world except the player location. So they may not be suitable for every area in your game.
• Use the Transform variable for simple adjustments only and not extreme repositioning of the level sequences.
• The widgets in this system consist of modular elements.
<li>All of them perform different functions -
• E_Button: A reusable button element with customization for color, text, state and other properties.
Uses SetButtonStatus function to change button status.
• E_EmptyHorizontal: Empty widget element intended for E_HorizontallyStackedWidgetElements.
• E_EmptyVertical: Empty widget element intended for E_VerticallyStackedWidgetElements.
• E_FixedText: For text on screen which never changes.
• E_GameTitle: Image widget element. Whever an image is needed, just put it in.
Uses SetNewImage function to change image dynamically.
• E_HorizontallyStackedWidgetElements: Similar to HorizontalBox, but with extended functionalities for appending other widget elements dynamically (not during runtime) and control their properties.
• E_PairedElement: Similar to E_HorizontallyStackedWidgetElements but only for two elements.
• E_PairedText: Similar to E_PairedElement but for text only.
Uses SetPairTextValue function to change value of right side text in a pair dynamically.
• E_VariableText: For on-screen text that even changes slightly.
Uses SetNewText function to change text dynamically.
• E_VerticallyStackedWidgetElements: Similar to VerticalBox, but with extended functionalities for appending other widget elements dynamically (not during runtime) and control their properties.

Child widgets added to Stacked Arrays during Pre-Construct (for live preview) become locked in the Details panel. To edit a child widget, remove it from the slot -> Compile, make your changes, and add it back and Compile again!
• These are recurring set of properties for almost all the elements and they do exactly what the title says.
• Some elements may or may not utilize all the fields here.
• Elements such as Buttons, Text etc; once added to SlotWidgetElement will no longer be editable.
• Remove them the slot and compile the blueprint. Now you can edit the respective element again.
• Sometimes removing elements from slots or pressing Ctrl+Z during editing the widget blueprint may show many copies of an element even though it has been assigned to a slot element.
• Worry not. Just compile the blueprint and everything should be normal again.
